docs.snippet: Jason Pierre-Paul, who was unproductive last season after back surgery, said people had been too quick to declare his days as a Pro Bowl-caliber defensive end over....
docs.lead_paragraph: Jason Pierre-Paul, who was unproductive last season after back surgery, said people had been too quick to declare his days as a Pro Bowl-caliber defensive end over.
docs.abstract: New York Giants defensive end Jason Pierre-Paul, who underwent back surgery last season, says he is ready to prove himself in the 2014-2015 NFL season; other football news noted.

headline.main: Giants’ Jason Pierre-Paul Says He Is Healthy

docs.snippet: The United States Patent and Trademark Office said “a substantial composite of Native Americans found the term Redskins to be disparaging.”...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States Patent and Trademark Office said “a substantial composite of Native Americans found the term Redskins to be disparaging.”
docs.abstract: United States Patent and Trademark Office rules that Washington Redskins team name is disparaging and strips NFL team of federal protections for six of its trademarks; ruling is latest indication of mounting disapproval of one of the league's most established and lucrative brands, and is likely to amplify strident debate at the crossroads of politics, sports and money.

headline.main: Redskins Lose Ruling on Trademarks, but Fight Isn’t Over
headline.print_headline: Redskins Lose on Trademarks, but Fight Isn’t Over

byline.contributor: Carl Hulse contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By KEN BELSON and EDWARD WYATT

docs.snippet: A new trademark ruling undermines the Washington owner Daniel Snyder’s stated case for not making a change....
docs.lead_paragraph: A new trademark ruling undermines the Washington owner Daniel Snyder’s stated case for not making a change.

headline.main: Is This the Beginning of the End of the Redskins’ Team Name?

docs.snippet: A ruling to cancel the trademark registration of the name of the Washington Redskins because it is disparaging to American Indians was right....
docs.lead_paragraph: A ruling to cancel the trademark registration of the name of the Washington Redskins because it is disparaging to American Indians was right.
docs.abstract: Editorial supports Trademark Trial and Appeal Board ruling that six trademarks granted to owners of Washington Redskins football team should be canceled because name is disparaging to many American Indians; holds that team should reconsider its plan to appeal ruling and its refusal to change name that is offensive to many.

headline.seo: Will the Washington Redskins Change Its Name Now?

docs.snippet: California lawmakers on Thursday moved to restrict the number of football practices in which students are allowed to tackle each other, due to concerns that permanent brain damage could result from concussions among high school athletes....
docs.lead_paragraph: California lawmakers on Thursday moved to restrict the number of football practices in which students are allowed to tackle each other, due to concerns that permanent brain damage could result from concussions among high school athletes.

headline.main: California Bill Would Limit Football Practices to Reduce Concussions
headline.print_headline: California Bill Would Limit Football Practices to Reduce Concussions

docs.snippet: A new academic paper suggests that the word soccer began in Britain and was used there happily until at least the 1970s, even as a spirited debate over the sport’s name endures....
docs.lead_paragraph: A new academic paper suggests that the word soccer began in Britain and was used there happily until at least the 1970s, even as a spirited debate over the sport’s name endures.
docs.abstract: Academic paper published by Stefan Szymanski, economist who is a professor of sport management at the University of Michigan and the co-author of Soccernomics, suggests that the word soccer began in Britain and was used there happily until at least the 1970s, even as spirited debate over the sport's name endures; sport is called football almost everywhere, but not in the United States.

headline.seo: With World Cup in Headlines, a Debate Continues on What to Call the Game

docs.lead_paragraph: The most instructive line in the Oscar-winning "Deer Hunter" isn't delivered by Robert De Niro or Christopher Walken's suicidal character Nick but by an oily Frenchman in the embers of Vietnam War-time Saigon who tut-tuts disapprovingly when Nick turns down a glass of champagne.
